features.description: A colorless, odorless gas that interferes with the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.
features.health_effects: Headaches, dizziness, unconsciousness, death (in high concentrations).
features.sources: Incomplete combustion of fossil fuels (vehicles, stoves, furnaces).

features.description: A harmful form of ozone formed when sunlight reacts with pollutants like nitrogen oxides (NOx) and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
features.sources: Vehicle exhaust, industrial emissions, chemical solvents.

features.description: A group of gases including NO and NO₂ produced from high-temperature combustion.
features.health_effects: Respiratory issues, smog formation, acid rain.

features.description: A pungent, toxic gas primarily from burning fossil fuels.
features.health_effects: Eye irritation, respiratory problems, acid rain.

features.description: Heavy metal that was once common in fuel and industrial emissions.
features.health_effects: Brain and nervous system damage, especially in children.
features.sources: Old paints, industrial processes, leaded gasoline (still used in some countries).

features.description: Organic chemicals that easily evaporate and contribute to smog.
features.health_effects: Eye, nose, throat irritation, organ damage, cancer.
features.sources: Paints, cleaning supplies, fuels, industrial processes.

features.description: Tiny solid or liquid particles suspended in the air.
features.health_effects: Respiratory problems, heart disease, reduced lung function.

features.description: Pollutants known to cause serious health effects, including cancer.
features.sources: Chemical manufacturing, waste incineration, fuel combustion.
Tobacco smoke, cooking stoves, mold, cleaning products.
